questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for bedwetting. He went 2 months without wetting the bed but then started again 6 weeks ago. He has been wetting the bed about 1–2 times per week. He has not had daytime urinary incontinence or dysuria. His teachers report that he is attentive in preschool and plays well with his peers. He is able to name 5 colors, follow three-step commands, and recite his address. He can do a somersault, use scissors, and copy a square. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An enuresis alarm is a moisture sensor placed in underwear and triggers an alarm upon micturition with the purpose of waking the patient. This conditioning trains children to wake up before urinating, thus preventing enuresis. Enuresis alarms are the first-line treatment for nocturnal enuresis in children who do not respond to behavioral modifications (e.g., frequent voiding, evening fluid restriction, motivational therapy). Since bedwetting is not considered abnormal before the age of 5 years, this patient does not meet criteria for diagnosis of nocturnal enuresis. Enuresis alarms are not indicated in this patient at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Bladder training exercises involve practicing holding in urine after drinking water or waiting as long as possible to void during the day in order to expand bladder capacity and train pelvic muscles. This strategy is uncomfortable, trains children to not respond to the sensation of a full bladder, and has been shown to be ineffective.

C) INCORRECT:

Along with behavioral modifications (e.g., frequent voiding, evening fluid restriction), motivational therapy with a star chart or other reward systems is considered first-line treatment for nocturnal enuresis. Since bedwetting is not considered abnormal before the age of 5 years, this patient does not meet the criteria for diagnosis of nocturnal enuresis and therefore does not require motivational therapy.

D) CORRECT:

Nocturnal enuresis is defined as involuntary nighttime voiding of urine for ≥ 3 months in children aged ≥ 5 years. Since bedwetting is considered normal in children aged < 5 years, this boy's parents can be reassured that no further management is required at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin therapy is indicated for nocturnal enuresis after initial therapies of behavioral modification (e.g., evening water restriction, regular voiding, motivational therapy) and enuresis alarms have failed. It can also be used as an alternative first-line intervention to enuresis alarms in families who desire rapid and/or short-term improvement. Since bedwetting is not considered abnormal before the age of 5 years, desmopressin therapy is not indicated in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Urinalysis should be performed when a patient is diagnosed with nocturnal enuresis to help rule out underlying causes such as urinary tract infections, diabetes mellitus, diabetes insipidus, or proteinuria (suggestive of kidney disease). Since bedwetting is not considered abnormal before the age of 5 years, this patient does not meet criteria for diagnosis of nocturnal enuresis and therefore does not require urinalysis. Moreover, he does not have any other symptoms, e.g., fever, weight loss, dysuria, urgency, or daytime incontinence, that might suggest an underlying disease.
questions.hint: Recommendations for managing nocturnal enuresis depend on the child's age.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-month history of stool incontinence. He was potty-trained at 4 years but now soils in his clothes 1–2 times a month and does not seem to notice when he needs to go to the bathroom. He now sleeps with pull-up diapers at night and he frequently urinates in them. He has large, hard stools and painful bowel movements once a week. They moved to a new town 5 months ago and the patient has had trouble adjusting. He also started school a few months ago, which according to the mother “only made things worse.” He has bronchial asthma well controlled with a corticosteroid inhaler, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder for which he takes methylphenidate. He eats a regular diet but dislikes vegetables apart from green peas and potatoes. He is at the 50th percentile for weight and 25th percentile for height. His temperature is 36.7°C (96.1°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 98/60 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is mildly distended and there is firmness to palpation in the left lower quadrant; there is no guarding or rebound. Digital rectal examination shows a normal sphincter tone. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An x-ray of the abdomen can be used to evaluate for potential causes of encopresis (e.g., fecal mass in the rectosigmoid colon) in patients who have no history of constipation or in whom an abdominal and/or rectal digital examination is not possible (e.g., due to obesity, refusal). This patient's history and physical examination findings are consistent with constipation, for which an abdominal x-ray is not required. In patients with constipation, the digital rectal examination may show a distended rectum filled with stool. However, a normal digital rectal exam does not exclude the diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

A high-fiber diet may be considered for the management and prevention of constipation, which this patient has. Although patients with constipation benefit from long-term dietary interventions, another more urgent management step is required at this time.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical and physical findings are consistent with retentive encopresis, the most common type of encopresis. Symptoms typically develop as a result of underlying constipation and stool impaction, with consequent overflow past the impaction and soiling of underwear. Retentive encopresis develops when the urge to defecate is suppressed; triggering situations include starting school (e.g., due to limited time, lack of privacy, unhygienic toilets), and avoidance of painful defecation (e.g., constipation, anal fissures). In younger children, constipation can develop during potty training or the transition to solid food. Treatment consists of fecal disimpaction with enemas or oral agents (polyethylene glycol), followed by maintenance laxative therapy for 6–24 months. An ongoing healthy high-fiber diet along with age-appropriate physical activity is also recommended. For children with encopresis, additional behavioral interventions (e.g., regular toilet regimen, positive reinforcement), cognitive behavioral therapy, and biofeedback training (to improve control of perianal musculature) should be considered.

Encopresis itself can cause significant psychological distress in children. Parents should therefore be advised to support their children and provide positive feedback and reinforcement throughout the entire duration of treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Biofeedback is an adjuvant technique in the management of retentive encopresis that helps patients to improve control of their anal sphincter and perianal muscles. Before considering biofeedback training, however, another step is more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up may be appropriate in children who have just started toilet training and still have incomplete bowel control (typically in those < 4 years of age). This 6-year-old patient, however, was toilet-trained 2 years ago and has had good bowel control until 3 months ago, which suggests a nonphysiologic cause of his symptoms.

F) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the lumbosacral spine can be performed in a patient with lumbar spinal cord lesions (e.g., spina bifida occulta, meningomyelocele), which can manifest with fecal and urinary incontinence. However, this patient has no other signs of a spinal cord lesion (e.g., abnormal sphincter tone, muscle weakness). His presentation is more consistent with constipation, which is the most likely cause of his fecal incontinence. Because of the close proximity of the rectum, anus, and urinary tract, urinary incontinence often occurs simultaneously with constipation (e.g., due to compression of the bladder, changes in neural stimulation to the bladder and pelvic floor).
questions.hint: According to the DSM-5 criteria, encopresis is defined as the involuntary elimination of feces in children ≥ 4 years in inappropriate settings for their developmental age (e.g., in their clothes, on the floor), occurring more than once a month for ≥ 3 months. Encopresis is classified as either retentive or nonretentive. This patient’s history (large, hard stools with painful bowel movements, nocturia) and physical examination findings (mild abdominal distension, firmness in the left lower quadrant) indicate that he has retentive encopresis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 1-month history of bedwetting about 2–3 times per week. He previously went 1 year without wetting the bed. The mother reports that she and her husband have been monitoring their son's voiding habits over the past month. He passes stool of normal color and consistency approximately once daily and voids his bladder 5–7 times per day. He drinks little during dinner and before going to bed. They have not noticed any urgency, hesitancy, straining, postmicturition dribble, or episodes of urinary incontinence during the day. The patient says that he has no pain in his abdominal or genital region prior to, during, or after voiding. He recently started primary school and says he enjoys it. He is able to balance and hop on one foot, tie a knot, name 6 colors, and dress with minimal assistance from his parents. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin therapy is indicated for patients ≥ 7 years of age with nocturnal enuresis if nonpharmacological measures (e.g., fluid restriction at night, timed voiding, enuresis alarm) are unsuccessful or if more rapid improvement is desired. However, organic causes of secondary enuresis should be ruled out before initiating treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Urological imaging (e.g., a voiding cystourethrogram) is used to diagnose urinary tract abnormalities in patients with secondary enuresis who have findings such as symptoms of urinary tract obstruction, a history of multiple urinary tract infections, and significant urinary symptoms during the daytime. This patient has no such findings that suggest urinary tract abnormalities.

C) CORRECT:

Urinalysis is indicated in all patients with nocturnal enuresis to exclude organic causes, such as occult urinary tract infection, diabetic ketoacidosis, and diabetes insipidus. In addition to urinalysis, a detailed history, a voiding diary, and a physical examination should be completed prior to initiating treatment. Secondary enuresis is typically caused by an underlying condition (e.g., constipation, obstructive sleep apnea, urinary tract abnormalities, certain psychiatric disorders) or new psychosocial stressors (e.g., starting primary school). Treatment includes nonpharmacological measures (e.g., fluid restriction at night, psychoeducation, timed voiding), training with an enuresis alarm, pharmacotherapy (e.g., desmopressin), and management of any underlying conditions (e.g., antibiotics for urinary tract infection).

D) INCORRECT:

Enuresis alarms are a first-line therapy for patients < 7 years of age with nocturnal enuresis who do not respond to behavioral modifications (e.g., timed voiding, fluid restriction at night, psychoeducation). However, this patient is 7 years old, and organic causes of secondary enuresis should be ruled out before initiating treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up are appropriate for children < 5 years because bedwetting is normal for this age. This patient is 7 years old and presents with secondary enuresis, which warrants another step in management.
questions.hint: A child who previously achieved nocturnal continence and has begun to wet the bed again has secondary enuresis.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old boy presents, with his mother, for evaluation of nighttime enuresis. The patient states that he really wants to be dry at night.
Further history reveals that the child has been continent of stool and urine during the day since age 4, with no daytime accidents. He wears two absorbent pads to bed and wakes with the pads and underlying bed “always wet.” He reports that he has soft bowel movements every other day and does not strain to pass them. His mother reports that he is a very heavy sleeper.
The boy’s younger sister, who has type 1 diabetes, achieved nighttime continence at age 6. The boy’s father achieved nighttime continence at age 11. The mother is unsure of her own timing of continence.
The boy's vital signs, growth parameters, and physical examination are normal. A urinalysis, obtained in the office, is unremarkable.
Which one of the following initial steps is most appropriate in addressing this boy’s nighttime incontinence?

choices.text: Check a fingerstick glucose level in the office
Recommend use of a 1- to 2-week bladder and bowel diary

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diabetes-related polyuria would be identified by a urinalysis finding of glycosuria. A fingerstick test is not indicated; moreover, this child’s history does not suggest diabetes.

B) INCORRECT:

Imaging (a voiding cystourethrogram) is not required when the history suggests typical MNE.

C) CORRECT:

In children 5 years of age or older, monosymptomatic nocturnal enuresis (MNE) is defined as urinary incontinence during sleep that is not associated with other urinary dysfunction. Boys are affected more often than girls. Although most MNE eventually resolves spontaneously, it causes great distress for many children.

History is the critical step in evaluating enuresis. Clinicians should ask about urinary urgency, constipation, voiding patterns, fluid intake, and daytime incontinence. A history of needing abdominal pressure to urinate, a weak urinary stream, or constant leaking should prompt referral to a specialist. Diaries of intake, voiding times, and volumes are more reliable than family recall and can aid in the evaluation of MNE. The diary should be kept for 1 to 2 weeks.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial evaluation of monosymptomatic nocturnal enuresis involves use of a bladder and bowel diary.

D) INCORRECT:

Constipation must also be considered in the evaluation of MNE. A diary, including parental observation of stool consistency and size, may inform decisions about treatment. This child has stools every other day, but they are soft and there is no straining. Therefore, he does not need polyethylene glycol.

E) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin may be considered for treating MNE but only after a thorough history is obtained. Families should be counseled to avoid excess fluid intake for 2 hours before the use of desmopressin and until the dose wears off in the morning to reduce the risk for hyponatremia. An intranasal formulation of desmopressin was associated with increased risk of hyponatremia and subsequent seizures and is no longer indicated for the treatment of enuresis.

questions.text:
A healthy 7-year-old girl reports bedwetting. She has been using the toilet regularly during the day since age 3 and has been wearing underwear to bed for 6 months, but she is wet most mornings and would like to be dry. She takes no medications.
She has one to two soft bowel movements each day that she does not have to strain to expel. If her parents wake her when they are going to bed, she will urinate but still ends up wetting the bed later in the night. She also reports changing underwear at school several times each week because of small “accidents.” She notes that she pushes on her abdomen to void.
Her vital signs, growth parameters, and physical examination are normal. A urinalysis is unremarkable.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate use of a continence alarm

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Constipation is a frequent contributor to NMNE and LUTD. However, there is no evidence of constipation in this case, making treatment with polyethylene glycol unnecessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Continence alarms are first-line therapies for monosymptomatic nocturnal enuresis but are frequently unsuccessful in NMNE if used before LUTD is corrected.

C) INCORRECT:

All patients with enuresis should be screened for comorbid psychiatric illnesses, such as attention deficit-hyperactivity disorder. If there is no anatomical or neurologic abnormality, interventions such as biofeedback may be useful.

D) INCORRECT:

Nocturnal desmopressin is first-line therapy for monosymptomatic nocturnal enuresis but is frequently unsuccessful in NMNE if used before LUTD is corrected.

E) CORRECT:

Up to one-third of children with nocturnal enuresis also suffer from daytime incontinence, a disorder called nonmonosymptomatic nocturnal enuresis (NMNE). Symptoms of urgency, frequency, and daytime wetting suggest lower urinary tract dysfunction (LUTD). Evaluation for bladder-muscle overactivity, large postvoid residuals, and small bladder volumes would all be considered. Typically, patients with NMNE are referred for urologic evaluation. If there is any history of weak urinary stream or use of abdominal pressure to void (as in this case), prompt referral to a specialist is essential.

Key learning point: For children with nocturnal enuresis and daytime incontinence, the most appropriate reason for referral to a specialist is associated lower urinary tract dysfunction.

questions.text:
A healthy 4-year-old boy who was toilet trained by his third birthday has been frequently soiling his underwear with liquid stool for the past 6 months. He typically has a bowel movement in the toilet once per week but soils himself 4 to 5 days per week. The boy’s father says that his son often strains with bowel movements, sometimes passing very large firm stools, and is embarrassed when he soils himself. There have been no recent injuries, stressors, or inciting events.
His abdomen is full but nontender, and a palpable stool ball is noted on rectal examination.
A trial without cow’s milk and of increased fiber and exercise has not resulted in symptomatic improvement.
What is the most appropriate initial management in this case?

choices.text: Introduce a positive reward system to encourage use of the toilet
Initiate treatment with daily polyethylene glycol

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Controlled trials of probiotics in children with constipation have failed to demonstrate efficacy and so are not recommended as the sole management modality.

B) INCORRECT:

A positive reward system is unlikely to be effective for a child who experiences pain or discomfort during bowel movements or is already embarrassed by the encopresis.

C) INCORRECT:

Anorectal manometry is indicated only in cases of encopresis that are recalcitrant to medication management or in patients with high suspicion for Hirschsprung disease. Hirschsprung disease typically manifests early in the newborn period with abdominal distention and failure to pass meconium within the first 48 hours of life.

D) INCORRECT:

Over-the-counter products to relieve diarrhea, such as bismuth subsalicylate, are not appropriate for the management of encopresis. Furthermore, these products are not indicated in children because of the risk of excess fluid loss, and products that contain salicylates can put children at risk for Reye syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

This boy is experiencing encopresis, or repeated involuntary fecal soiling that is not due to another organic cause. The amount of soiling in encopresis may vary from a smear to a regular bowel movement. Fear of passing painful stool and frequent withholding of stool cause leakage around an impacted fecal mass in the rectum. Typically, children achieve fecal continence by 4 years of age, so encopresis rarely occurs before age 3. The prevalence of encopresis is 3% among 4-year-olds and 1.6% among 10-year-olds. It is more common in boys than girls. At least 80% of children with functional fecal incontinence have underlying constipation, and this child’s history is consistent with a diagnosis of constipation. The most effective treatment for constipation and functional incontinence in children is a stool softener, typically polyethylene glycol.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial care for a young child who is experiencing encopresis is treatment with polyethylene glycol.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of a 1-month history of bedwetting about 2–3 times per week. He previously went 1 year without wetting the bed. He passes stool of normal color and consistency approximately once daily and voids his bladder 5–7 times per day. His parents have not noticed any urgency, hesitancy, straining, postmicturition dribble, or episodes of urinary incontinence during the day. The patient says that he has no pain in his abdominal or genital region prior to, during, or after voiding. He recently started primary school and says he enjoys it. He is able to balance and hop on one foot, tie a knot, name 6 colors, and dress with minimal assistance from his parents. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin therapy is indicated for patients ≥ 7 years of age with nocturnal enuresis if nonpharmacological measures (e.g., fluid restriction at night, timed voiding, enuresis alarm) are unsuccessful or if more rapid improvement is desired. However, organic causes of secondary enuresis should be ruled out before initiating treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Urological imaging (e.g., a voiding cystourethrogram) is used to diagnose urinary tract abnormalities in patients with secondary enuresis who have findings such as symptoms of urinary tract obstruction, a history of multiple urinary tract infections, and significant urinary symptoms during the daytime. This patient has no such findings that suggest urinary tract abnormalities.

C) CORRECT:

Urinalysis is indicated in all patients with nocturnal enuresis to exclude organic causes, such as occult urinary tract infection, diabetic ketoacidosis, and diabetes insipidus. In addition to urinalysis, a detailed history, a voiding diary, and a physical examination should be completed prior to initiating treatment. Secondary enuresis is typically caused by an underlying condition (e.g., constipation, obstructive sleep apnea, urinary tract abnormalities, certain psychiatric disorders) or new psychosocial stressors (e.g., starting primary school). Treatment includes nonpharmacological measures (e.g., fluid restriction at night, psychoeducation, timed voiding), training with an enuresis alarm, pharmacotherapy (e.g., desmopressin), and management of any underlying conditions (e.g., antibiotics for urinary tract infection).

D) INCORRECT:

Enuresis alarms are a first-line therapy for patients < 7 years of age with nocturnal enuresis who do not respond to behavioral modifications (e.g., timed voiding, fluid restriction at night, psychoeducation). However, this patient is 7 years old, and organic causes of secondary enuresis should be ruled out before initiating treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up are appropriate for children < 5 years because bedwetting is normal for this age. This patient is 7 years old and presents with secondary enuresis, which warrants another step in management.
questions.hint: A child who previously achieved nocturnal continence and has begun to wet the bed again has secondary enuresis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 4-year-old boy brought to your clinic by his parents because of bedwetting. He had a 2-month period without bedwetting, but began wetting the bed again 6 weeks ago, now occurring about 1–2 times per week. He has not had any daytime urinary incontinence or dysuria. His preschool teachers report that he is attentive and plays well with peers. He is able to name 5 colors, follow three-step commands, recite his address, do a somersault, use scissors, and copy a square. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin therapy is indicated for nocturnal enuresis after initial therapies of behavioral modification (e.g., evening water restriction, regular voiding, motivational therapy) and enuresis alarms have failed. It can also be used as an alternative first-line intervention to enuresis alarms in families who desire rapid and/or short-term improvement. Since bedwetting is not considered abnormal before the age of 5 years, desmopressin therapy is not indicated in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Urinalysis should be performed when a patient is diagnosed with nocturnal enuresis to help rule out underlying causes such as urinary tract infections, diabetes mellitus, diabetes insipidus, or proteinuria (suggestive of kidney disease). Since bedwetting is not considered abnormal before the age of 5 years, this patient does not meet criteria for diagnosis of nocturnal enuresis and therefore does not require urinalysis. Moreover, he does not have any other symptoms, e.g., fever, weight loss, dysuria, urgency, or daytime incontinence, that might suggest an underlying disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Bladder training exercises involve practicing holding in urine after drinking water or waiting as long as possible to void during the day in order to expand bladder capacity and train pelvic muscles. This strategy is uncomfortable, trains children to not respond to the sensation of a full bladder, and has been shown to be ineffective.

D) INCORRECT:

An enuresis alarm is a moisture sensor placed in underwear and triggers an alarm upon micturition with the purpose of waking the patient. This conditioning trains children to wake up before urinating, thus preventing enuresis. Enuresis alarms are the first-line treatment for nocturnal enuresis in children who do not respond to behavioral modifications (e.g., frequent voiding, evening fluid restriction, motivational therapy). Since bedwetting is not considered abnormal before the age of 5 years, this patient does not meet criteria for diagnosis of nocturnal enuresis. Enuresis alarms are not indicated in this patient at this time.

E) CORRECT:

Nocturnal enuresis is defined as involuntary nighttime voiding of urine for ≥ 3 months in children aged ≥ 5 years. Since bedwetting is considered normal in children aged < 5 years, this boy's parents can be reassured that no further management is required at this time.

Key learning point: Bedwetting is normal in children under 5 years old and requires only reassurance, not further evaluation or treatment.
questions.hint: Recommendations for managing nocturnal enuresis depend on the child's age.
